column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Discussion
#Text=Twenty-two of the included studies used a cross-sectional design , whereas three adopted a case-control design .
#Text=The methodological quality of most of the studies ranged from moderate to strong ( Table 1 and Table 2 ) .
#Text=The reasons for these studies not achieving a higher quality standard were often because of the following :
#Text=The time for the research objects was not well defined ;
#Text=Convenience sampling or a lack of sampling strategy/randomization was used ;

#Text=No proper sample size estimation was calculated , particularly in reference to the nature of the dependent variable and number of independent variables to be analyzed and the subsequent regression analyses , including the control protocol for the confounders .
#Text=The methodological quality of these studies may also affect the quality of this review .

#Text=Because these studies were cross-sectional and examined the outcome measures at one point in time , the lack of a longitudinal design , randomization , and/or comparison methods may affect the validity and consistency of the results on oral health problems and the factors associated with oral health among institutionalized residents .

#Text=In general , the included 25 studies/series exhibited no standardized reporting style and some did not include clear a summary of the primary data or essential background information of the surveyed residents .
#Text=As a result , only a small proportion of studies reported the dependency level , malnutrition risks , MCI/dementia proportion or systemic conditions .

#Text=Concerning oral health and OHRQoL data , the situation appeared slightly better ; however , the varied recording protocol and disease categorization criteria also limited the generalizability of the observations across different reports .
#Text=This review investigated the relationship between the aspects of oral health and the associated factors on oral health problems and the OHRQoL among the institutionalized elderly population .
#Text=The results confirm that this population comprises vulnerable people who have poor oral health because they are relatively weak and dependent .
#Text=The identified non-modifiable and modifiable factors associated with vulnerable oral health among this underprivileged group could be categorized as individual or environmental factors .
#Text=Individual factors are most likely due to limited physical functioning and/or cognitive impairment , leading to a limited self-care ability .
#Text=Although the limited data could be extracted and therefore reported in this review , non-communicable diseases are common in elderly , institutionalized or not .
#Text=The current report suggests the non-communicable diseases likely to increase physical inability and self-care dependence .

#Text=Based on the evidence-based findings of the relevant included studies over the past decade , the institutionalized elderly population is at increased odds to have poor oral health with various degrees of dental , periodontal , oral mucosal and TMJ problems and poor functions due to missing teeth , inadequate replacement or poor dentures .
#Text=Oral problems cause oral distress , poor function and a deprived OHRQoL .
#Text=Chronic oral distress and poor chewing function could affect general health , such as through the increased risk of malnourishment .
#Text=The outcomes of this review are comparable to those of the previous findings .
#Text=Notably , maintaining oral hygiene is a decisive factor in good oral and general health .

#Text=The oral examinations were performed by dentists , dental hygienists , dental/hygienist students , trained ward nurses or calibrated examiners using varied protocols , with some not accounted for in detail .
#Text=With that , the outcomes of the oral health evaluations were diverse and , oftentimes , non-generalizable and hard to compare .

#Text=Nevertheless , this review found that poor oral hygiene in residents was probably due to inadequate teeth/denture brushing or cleaning , which increases the prevalence of dental problems and periodontal diseases or other severe complications .

#Text=In addition , in this special group , the related predisposing factors were considered to be MCI/dementia , high care dependency and lack of access ( except in a few North American institutions ) to dental and oral care .
#Text=The most common dental problems included large amounts of plaque , debris and calculus and moderate to advanced periodontitis .
#Text=Periodontitis is a common oral problem in middle age or elderly populations , particularly in institutional residents .
#Text=All residents were found to have plaque and more than 70 % of residents had plaque covering one index tooth .
#Text=Poor oral hygiene indicates a higher possibility of gingivitis , periodontitis , periodontal attachment loss and tooth loss .
#Text=In the elderly population suffering from hyposalivation due to ageing or concurrent medications , caries of crown and roots , tooth loss and so on are common .
#Text=Dental problems also increase the risk of oral health complications and general health problems .
